Toasted Level Manager/source/LevelManager.c

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /***************************************************************************
00002         Author: Sheridan Beebe
00003         Game:   Toasted
00004         File:   driver.c
00005         Date:   January 16th, 2007
00006         Description:
00007                         This file contains all the source code for the level management
00008                         functions. All methods are prototyped in LevelManager.h, and
00009                         all types are declared there as well. The main purpose of this
00010                         file and these functions is to provide the core functionality
00011                         that will allow us to load and manage a level for game play.
00012 ***************************************************************************/
00013 
00014 /* include the LevelManager.h header, contains everything we need. */
00015 #include "LevelManager.h"
00016 
00017 /*! \brief This function performs some necessary initialization.
00018 
00019    It must be called before the level system can ever be used! 
00020 
00021    \sa unloadLevelManager()
00022 */
00023 void loadLevelManager()
00024 {
00025         /* create a level position to be used by all whitespace */
00026         whiteSpacePosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_SPACE, ' ');
00027         
00028         /* create a level position to be used by all walls */
00029         wallPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_WALL, 'X');
00030 }
00031 
00032 /*! \brief This function performs the necessary clean up for the level manager.
00033 
00034    It is important that this be called before the program exits. 
00035    However, the level manager must NOT be used once this has been called.
00036    If it is, in any way, we could end up with invalid pointers.
00037    All level's should be unloaded also before this is called. 
00038 
00039    \sa loadLevelManager()
00040 */
00041 void unloadLevelManager()
00042 {
00043         /* free the universal white space struct... */
00044         free(whiteSpacePosition);
00045         
00046         /* free the universal wall position struct... */
00047         free(wallPosition);
00048 }
00049 
00050 /*! \brief Load a new level
00051 
00052         This is the main function that should be called in order to load a new
00053         level. Loading a new level will set the level to be the current level.
00054 
00055    \param fileName      - A pointer to a character array that 
00056                                         contains the file name of the map to
00057                                         be loaded.
00058         \return Returns a pointer to the LEVEL that was loaded. It is best to not
00059                                         use this pointer directly, but instead, use getCurrentLevel()
00060                                         to obtain a pointer to the currentLevel (in most cases).
00061                                         This way you can be sure you don't use an invalid pointer later.
00062         \sa unloadLevel()
00063 */
00064 LEVEL* loadLevel(char *fileName)
00065 {
00066         /* load the file */
00067         FILE *levelFile;
00068 
00069         /* line buffer to hold in each line as we read it */
00070         char lineBuffer[LONGEST_LINE] = {0};
00071 
00072         /* this will hold the longest line we've read - to calculate level width */
00073         int longestLine = 0;
00074 
00075         /* this will count the number of lines in the file - to calculate the level
00076                 height */
00077     int lineCount = 0;
00078 
00079         /* this will track the current y value, starts at the top, so 0. */
00080         int currentY = 0;
00081 
00082         /* these values used for setting all the spaces to white spaces initial */
00083         int layerCounter = 0, xCounter = 0, yCounter = 0;
00084 
00085         /* time to load a level, woot. */
00086         /* create a new LEVEL for the level we are loading */
00087         LEVEL *level = malloc(sizeof(LEVEL));
00088 
00089         /* fill in some starting info, the file name for instance. */
00090         strcpy(&level->fileName[0], fileName);
00091 
00092         /* open the file in read-text mode */
00093         levelFile = fopen(level->fileName, "rt");
00094 
00095         /* read through the file once to find out the levels dimensions. */
00096         if(levelFile == NULL)
00097         {
00098                 printf("Error: could not load level file ");
00099         }
00100         else
00101         {
00102                 /* loop through the entire file and read information on its size and such */
00103                 while(fgets(&lineBuffer[0], LONGEST_LINE, levelFile) != NULL)
00104                 {
00105                         /* store this lines length */
00106                         int lineLength = 0;
00107                         lineLength = (int)strlen(&lineBuffer[0]) - 1;
00108 
00109                         /* increase the line count */
00110                         lineCount++;
00111 
00112                         /* check to see if this line's length is the longest */
00113                         if(lineLength > longestLine)
00114                         {
00115                                 /* set the new longest line length to this line's length */
00116                                 longestLine = lineLength;
00117                         }
00118                 }
00119 
00120                 /* now that we know the level's width and height, store it */
00121                 level->width = longestLine;
00122                 level->height = lineCount;
00123 
00124                 /* set this level to be the current level */
00125                 setCurrentLevel(level);
00126 
00127                 /* now that we know the level's size, we need to create an array to store each position */
00128                 level->firstPosition = (LEVEL_POSITION**)malloc(sizeof(LEVEL_POSITION*) * level->width * level->height
00129                         * LAYER_COUNT);
00130 
00131                 /* now that we have the space, fill it in with each character */
00132 
00133                 /* we'll initialy fill it with spaces. this way we don't have to worry about it later */
00134                 /* loop through every layer */
00135                 for(layerCounter = 0; layerCounter < LAYER_COUNT; layerCounter++)
00136                 {
00137                         /* loop through every line */
00138                         for(yCounter = 0; yCounter < level->height; yCounter++)
00139                         {
00140                                 /* loop through each character */
00141                                 for(xCounter = 0; xCounter < level->width; xCounter++)
00142                                 {
00143                                         setLevelPosition(layerCounter, xCounter, yCounter, whiteSpacePosition);
00144                                 }
00145                         }
00146                 }
00147                 
00148                 /* rewind the file to the beginning */
00149                 rewind(levelFile);
00150 
00151                 /* loop through the entire file and read information and create our level */
00152                 while(fgets(&lineBuffer[0], LONGEST_LINE, levelFile) != NULL)
00153                 {
00154                         /* keep track of the current x position */
00155                         int currentX;
00156                         for(currentX = 0; currentX < level->width; currentX++)
00157                         {
00158                                 /* check to see what this space contains. */
00159                                 if(lineBuffer[currentX] == ' ')
00160                                 {
00161                                         /* the positions are already full of white spaces, so theres no need
00162                                                 to do anything here. */
00163                                 }
00164                                 else if(lineBuffer[currentX] == 'X')
00165                                 {
00166                                         /* theres a wall here, set the proper level position to a wall */
00167                                         setLevelPosition(WALL_LAYER, currentX, currentY, wallPosition);
00168                                 }
00169                                 else if(lineBuffer[currentX] == 'E')
00170                                 {
00171                                         /* create a new LEVEL_POSITION for this enemy */
00172                                         LEVEL_POSITION *enemyPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_ENEMY, 'E');
00173 
00174                                         /* inform the enemy system, ie. newEnemy(x, y, enemyPositin);
00175                                            make sure newEnemy() returns a pointer to the enemy structure, and store it
00176                                            in enemyPosition->data. */
00177 
00178                                         /* put the enemyPosition into the correct position */
00179                                         setLevelPosition(ENEMY_LAYER, currentX, currentY, enemyPosition);
00180 
00181                                         /* theres an enemy here, call the proper create function */
00182                                         printf("Found enemy at (%i,%i). Creating...\n", currentX, currentY);
00183                                 }
00184                                 else if(lineBuffer[currentX] == 'H')
00185                                 {
00186                                         /* theres a health pack here, call the proper create function */
00187 
00188                                         /* create a new health position */
00189                                         LEVEL_POSITION *healthPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_HEALTH, 'H');
00190 
00191                                         /* store it in the array */
00192                                         setLevelPosition(HEALTH_LAYER, currentX, currentY, healthPosition);
00193 
00194                                         printf("Found health pack at (%i,%i). Creating...\n", currentX, currentY);
00195                                 }
00196                                 else if(lineBuffer[currentX] == 'P')
00197                                 {
00198                                         /* create a new player position */
00199                                         LEVEL_POSITION *playerPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_PLAYER, 'P');
00200 
00201                                         /* store it in the array */
00202                                         setLevelPosition(PLAYER_LAYER, currentX, currentY, playerPosition);
00203 
00204                                         /* the player is here, call the proper create function */
00205                                         printf("Found player at (%i,%i). Creating...\n", currentX, currentY);
00206                                 }
00207                                 else if(lineBuffer[currentX] == 'W')
00208                                 {
00209                                         /* create a new weapon position */
00210                                         LEVEL_POSITION *weaponPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_WEAPON, 'W');
00211 
00212                                         /* store it in the array */
00213                                         setLevelPosition(WEAPON_LAYER, currentX, currentY, weaponPosition);
00214 
00215                                         /* theres a weapon here, call the proper create function */
00216                                         printf("Found weapon at (%i,%i). Creating...\n", currentX, currentY);
00217                                 }
00218                                 else if(lineBuffer[currentX] == 'S')
00219                                 {
00220                                         /* create a new health position */
00221                                         LEVEL_POSITION *switchPosition = createLevelPosition(NULL, POSITION_SWITCH, 'S');
00222 
00223                                         /* store it in the array */
00224                                         setLevelPosition(SWITCH_LAYER, currentX, currentY, switchPosition);
00225 
00226                                         /* theres a switch here, call the proper create function */
00227                                         printf("Found switch at (%i,%i). Creating...\n", currentX, currentY);
00228                                 }
00229                         }
00230                         
00231                         /* increment the y counter */
00232                         currentY++;
00233                 }
00234 
00235                 /* close the file now that we are finished with it */
00236                 fclose(levelFile);
00237         }
00238 
00239         return level;
00240 }

00242 /*! \brief This function is called to unload a level.
00243 
00244         The current level should always be unloaded before a new one
00245         is loaded, to ensure no memory leeks are created.
00246 
00247         \param level - A pointer to the level to be unloaded.
00248         \sa loadLevel()
00249 */
00250 void unloadLevel(LEVEL level)
00251 {
00252 
00253 }

00255 /*! \brief Get a pointer to the struct containing the info for a given level location.
00256 
00257         This is the main method used to determine what character is at a certain position.
00258         \param layerNumber - The layer number you wish to retrieve the LEVEL_POSITION for.
00259         \param x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION to be retrieved.
00260         \param y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION to be retrieved.
00261         \return A pointer to the LEVEL_POSITION located at the given values.
00262         \sa setLevelPosition()
00263 */
00264 LEVEL_POSITION *getLevelPosition(int layerNumber, int x, int y)
00265 {
00266         /* get the current level */
00267         LEVEL *level = getCurrentLevel();
00268 
00269         /* check to make sure the x and y are in the level's bounds,
00270            bad things could happen if they werent. */
00271         if(x < level->width && y < level->height && layerNumber < LAYER_COUNT)
00272         {
00273                 /* calculate the index value based on the x and y. */
00274                 int index = getPositionIndex(layerNumber, x, y);
00275                 LEVEL_POSITION *tmp = level->firstPosition[index];
00276                 return tmp;
00277         }
00278         else
00279         {
00280                 return NULL;
00281         }
00282 }
00283 
00284 /*! \brief Set the pointer to the LEVEL_POSITION containing the info for the given level location.
00285 
00286         This is the main method used to set the LEVEL_POSITION data for the positions in the LEVEL.
00287 
00288         \param layerNumber - The layer number you wish to set the LEVEL_POSITION for.
00289         \param x - The x value of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to set.
00290         \param y - The y value of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to set.
00291         \param newLevelPosition - A pointer to the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to set at the given
00292                                                         location.
00293         \sa getLevelPosition()
00294 */
00295 void setLevelPosition(int layerNumber, int x, int y, LEVEL_POSITION *newLevelPosition)
00296 {
00297         /* get a pointer to the current level */
00298         LEVEL *level = getCurrentLevel();
00299 
00300         if(x < level->width && y < level->height && layerNumber < LAYER_COUNT)
00301         {
00302                 /* calculate the index of the supplied x and y */
00303                 int index = getPositionIndex(layerNumber, x, y);
00304 
00305                 /* set the correct index to the supplied level position */
00306                 level->firstPosition[index] = newLevelPosition;
00307         }
00308         else
00309         {
00310                 printf("Error setting the level Position!\n");
00311         }
00312 }

00314 /*! \brief Quick convenience method to determine whether a location contains a space.
00315         
00316         This method is just a quick way to test to see if a certain level position is a space,
00317         since this will likely be needed a lot.
00318 
00319         \param layerNumber - The layer number of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
00320         \param x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
00321         \param y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
00322         \return Returns whether this position contains a space. 1 for yes, 0 for no.
00323         \sa isLevelPositionWall(), getLevelPosition()
00324 */
00325 int isLevelPositionSpace(int layerNumber, int x, int y)
00326 {
00327         /* call getLevelPosition, then return whether it was a space. */
00328         LEVEL_POSITION *position = getLevelPosition(layerNumber, x, y);
00329         if(position->type == POSITION_SPACE)
00330         {
00331                 /* return yes */
00332                 return 1;
00333         }
00334         else
00335         {
00336                 /* return no */
00337                 return 0;
00338         }
00339 }
00340 
00341 /*! \brief Quick convenience method returns whether a location contains a wall.
00342 
00343         This is just a quick way to determine if a specified position is a wall, since
00344         this is likely to be needed a lot.
00345 
00346         \param layerNumber - The layer number of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
00347         \param x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
00348         \param y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION you wish to check.
00349         \return Returns whether this position contains a wall. 1 for yes, 0 for no.
00350         \sa isLevelPositionSpace(), getLevelPosition()
00351 */
00352 int isLevelPositionWall(int layerNumber, int x, int y)
00353 {
00354         /* call getLevelPosition, then return whether it was a wall. */
00355         LEVEL_POSITION *position = getLevelPosition(layerNumber, x, y);
00356         if(position->type == POSITION_WALL)
00357         {
00358                 /* return yes */
00359                 return 1;
00360         }
00361         else
00362         {
00363                 /* return no */
00364                 return 0;
00365         }
00366 }

00368 /*! \brief Returns a pointer to the current level that is being used by the game.
00369 
00370         This method is used to get a pointer to the current level. Usually, this is the
00371         safest method since you won't be tryint to use an outdated level.
00372 
00373         \return A pointer to the current level in use.
00374         \sa setCurrentLevel()
00375 */
00376 LEVEL *getCurrentLevel()
00377 {
00378         /* return the pointer to the current level */
00379         return currentLevel;
00380 }
00381 
00382 /*! \brief Method for creating a new LEVEL_POSITION.
00383 
00384         This is an easy helper method to be used when creating a new LEVEL_POSITION 
00385         it uses malloc() so that it won't be released when it leaves scope. This
00386         means you MUST free it some time later. 
00387         
00388         \param data - A pointer to the data to be stored with the new LEVEL_POSITION.
00389                                 It can be used for what ever use you need, usualy for storing a
00390                                 pointer to this particular items other data, such as for an enemy
00391                                 or weapon.
00392         \param type - The type of object that is in this position, as defined by its
00393                                 POSITION_TYPE.
00394         \param character - The character to be displayed in this LEVEL_POSITION.
00395         \return A pointer to the newly created LEVEL_POSITION.
00396         \sa getLevelPosition(), setLevelPosition()
00397 */
00398 LEVEL_POSITION *createLevelPosition(void *data, POSITION_TYPE type, char character)
00399 {
00400         /* set asside the memory for the level position */
00401         LEVEL_POSITION *levelPosition = (LEVEL_POSITION*)malloc(sizeof(LEVEL_POSITION));
00402 
00403         /* ste the values to those that were passed in */
00404         levelPosition->data = data;
00405         levelPosition->type = type;
00406         levelPosition->character = character;
00407 
00408         /* return a pointer to the new level position */
00409         return levelPosition;
00410 }
00411 
00412 /*! \brief Sets the current level that the game should use.
00413 
00414         This is the main way to set the current level to be used. It should be
00415         noted that in most cases, calling this method directly is uneccesary, as 
00416         the loadLevel() function calls setCurrentLevel() itself.
00417 
00418         \param level - A pointer to the LEVEL to be set as the current level.
00419         \sa getCurrentLevel(), loadLevel()
00420 */
00421 void setCurrentLevel(LEVEL *level)
00422 {
00423         currentLevel = level;
00424 }
00425 
00426 /*! \brief This function calculates the index in the position pointer array
00427    that the specified layer x and y value is at. 
00428         
00429         This function is used to determine the location of a given LEVEL_POSITION
00430         based on the layer number, x, and y values. For the most part, this method
00431         should never be used directly. The functions getLevelPosition() and setLevelPosition()
00432         should provide a sufficient wrapper.
00433 
00434         \param layerNumber - The layer number of the LEVEL_POSITION index to be calculated.
00435         \param x - The x position of the LEVEL_POSITION index to be calculated.
00436         \param y - The y position of the LEVEL_POSITION index to be calculated.
00437         \return The index of the LEVEL_POSITION calculated by the input.
00438         \sa getLevelPosition(), setLevelPosition()
00439 */
00440 int getPositionIndex(int layerNumber, int x, int y)
00441 {
00442         /* get the current level */
00443         LEVEL *level = getCurrentLevel();
00444 
00445         /* calculate where in the square it is */
00446         int positionIndex = (level->width * y) + x;
00447 
00448         /* offset it by the layer number */
00449         positionIndex += (layerNumber * level->width * level->height);
00450 
00451         return positionIndex;
00452 }
